D37EB921F79A4261BAD382FD485EA0E4.description: describe similarities and differences between their community and a community in a different region in the world

11D18627BAF54FC698BF8F9263A5BB19.description: describe selected communities around the world, including at least one contemporary First Nation, Metis, or Inuit community, with reference to their major physical features, wildlife, and some aspects of their culture

FB8BD12120EC48709865F1B341E00FA1.description: identify basic human needs and describe some ways in which people in communities around the world meet these needs

AEFD1C774D664A14A0494CF03EBCB8D0.description: demonstrate the ability to extract information on the location and climate of a region from photographs and print, digital, and/or interactive maps

8BF75544EE3E4887BA4C9702012E9E6D.description: identify the location of selected countries, cities, and/or towns around the world, including at least one contemporary First Nation, Metis, or Inuit community, and describe how their location and climate are related

9073AC6D5F8B4359A0ADD0E539D502BD.description: identify cardinal directions on a map (i.e., N, S, E, W), and use these directions when locating selected communities, countries, and/or continents

C650D1DEA7DF4320839CC28B30E41536.description: identify continents, significant bodies of water, the equator, poles, and hemispheres, using a globe, print, digital, or interactive maps, and/or a mapping program

42AC8796F2D44090B78EB8B2752DB85A.description: demonstrate an understanding that there are a variety of countries, continents, physical features, and bodies of water around the world and that their locations can be represented in different ways

E20C6ECAD88046309D4239CC1DC84F01.description: Understanding Context: Physical Features and Communities - identify and locate various physical features and selected communities around the world, including at least one contemporary First Nation, M�tis, or Inuit community, and describe some aspects of people�s ways of life in those communities

B7BDA01F36154A04BF232523A7E3B753.description: communicate the results of their inquiries using appropriate vocabulary

13077C37F3774170A8ADE162471E872F.description: evaluate evidence and draw conclusions about some aspects of the interrelationship between communities' natural environment and the ways of life of people in those communities, including at least one contemporary First Nation, Metis, or Inuit community

2DF67FFA92D1408AACC892C72FBEFB21.description: interpret and analyse information and data relevant to their investigations, using a variety of tools

BFCAC129C9E94303844A2A7B0DCD11C4.description: analyse and construct simple maps to determine and illustrate patterns in the interrelationship between the location of some communities and human activities in those communities

EEBAC1FBCD044A24A42C9C67343E16DB.description: gather and organize information and data about some communities' locations, climate, and physical features, and the ways of life of people in these communities, including at least one contemporary First Nation, Metis, or Inuit community

661380327D6E41948C7361A8F8FE9559.description: formulate questions to guide investigations into some aspects of the interrelationship between the natural environment of selected communities, including at least one contemporary First Nation, Metis, or Inuit community, and the ways in which people live

A46BFF779A1E40069B863662F6555BC9.description: Inquiry: Natural Environments and Ways of Life  - use the social studies inquiry process to investigate aspects of the interrelationship between the natural environment, including the climate, of selected communities, including at least one contemporary First Nation, M�tis, or Inuit community, and the ways in which people in those communities live

D64E47C6D14B413F88983F468C1F8B9C.description: demonstrate an understanding of the importance of sustainability in people's interrelationship with their natural environment and of some of the consequences of sustainable and/or non-sustainable actions

288C221C39C1412BB1AB322356952C11.description: describe some of the ways in which two or more distinct communities have adapted to their location, climate, and physical features

898AF656E453497A9ACF38EDDB09B745.description: compare selected communities from around the world, including their own community, in terms of the lifestyles of people in those communities and some ways in which the people meet their needs

3619DEFBACD448CAB6B219ADF7E40980.description: Variations in Global Communities  - describe some similarities and differences in the ways in which people in two or more communities in different parts of the world meet their needs and have adapted to the location, climate, and physical features of their regions

0D5BEEC1DF39469889D33F150726F233.description: identify some ways in which heritage is passed on through various family celebrations and practices, including at least one First Nation, Metis, and/or Inuit family celebration or practice.

72AD441B541643E0B29E4368ACAA367A.description: identify some ways in which heritage is passed on through various community celebrations, traditions, teachings, ceremonies, and events.

78A9420360A24ABCB3D9C7ADC83AF54F.description: demonstrate an understanding of simple chronology by identifying and organizing chronologically some important events and/or people from multiple generations in their family and/or community.

4C8AC61E13E543F5A0CA908EF87AA9B4.description: describe some significant traditions and celebrations of their families, their peers, and their own communities, as well as of some other communities in Canada, including First Nations, Metis, and/or Inuit communities.

F8B05CC6739D43918448068A621230A0.description: identify places and/or countries of personal or familial significance, and locate them on a globe and/or print, digital, or interactive map.

B5468155C19A4E9C9C2EDF8D526BD8AA.description: identify various groups in their community and describe some of the ways in which their community reflects this diversity.

B10481B4D63940BC85031F7FAF5C82B0.description: identify and describe different types of families.

C9F9D3AE623649CCACFD63A6806FC000.description: Understanding Context: Tradition and Heritage - describe some of the major groups in their community, including First Nations, M�tis, and/or Inuit, other diverse communities, and different types of families, and some of the ways in which traditions and heritage are passed on by such groups.

098B1898211C4607B2382356090BE971.description: communicate the results of their inquiries, using appropriate vocabulary and formats.

2C21CD4CB53E44DBAEB8832B57C89444.description: evaluate evidence and draw conclusions about past and present traditions and celebrations in their own families and the communities to which they belong.

D5A80D329DD843B2A8CD72737A033240.description: interpret and analyse information relevant to their investigations, using a variety of tools.

3EEAA4C12EB7499DB7C29B017630FE58.description: analyse and construct simple maps as part of their investigations into past and present traditions and celebrations in their local community.

17F554009F294AAA8E788EAD64C9F89B.description: gather and organize information on some of the past and present traditions and celebrations within their family and the community to which they belong.

7E4E3F253FDA43ECA335D9A822E6FD77.description: formulate questions to guide investigations into some of the past and present traditions and celebrations in their own family and the communities to which they belong, using primary and/or secondary sources that they have gathered themselves or that have been provided to them

1F8118C318F043AF8A257F9CB3CE86A3.description: Inquiry: Past and Present Traditions - use the social studies inquiry process to investigate some of the past and present traditions and celebrations within their own family and the communities to which they belong.

911BB7417DE8422C8D5CE1960D616F60.description: identify some ways in which First Nations, Metis, and/or Inuit individuals, communities, and nations are reclaiming traditions, customs, teachings, and celebrations that were banned, lost, or practised in secret due to settlement and/or colonization, including the residential school system.

3E3C88A1A5454139BFCB617FD1158DC8.description: compare some of the past and present traditions and celebrations of various ethnocultural groups in their local community, and identify some of the main reasons for the change.

CB72E20AB1A04E279956492F63136E02.description: compare their family structure and some of their traditions and celebrations with those of their peers' families.

A9786F7017E543D18776C1B2F651B4D5.description: compare ways in which some traditions have been celebrated over multiple generations in their family and identify some of the main reasons for changes in these traditions.

D4E3F7D12B184812828CE6C1DD1BAB9C.description:
Application: Why Traditions Change - compare some significant traditions and celebrations among diverse groups and at different times, including those of First Nations, M�tis, and/or Inuit, and identify some of the reasons for changes in
these traditions/celebrations

BC1FAD0DEB2E41D286A263F331E31456.description: Heritage and Identity: Changing Family and Community Traditions
